title: 2 Men Convicted of Killing Malcolm X Will Be Exonerated After Decades
content: The 1966 convictions of the two men are expected to be thrown out after a lengthy investigation, validating long-held doubts about who killed the civil rights leader.

more_info.byline: By Ashley Southall and Jonah E. Bromwich

title: Overdose Deaths Reached Record High as the Pandemic Spread
content: More than 100,000 Americans died from drug overdoses in the yearlong period ending in April, government researchers said.

title: Vaccinated vs. Unvaccinated: Europe’s Covid Culture War
content: In pockets of Europe, vaccine resistance has become the long tail of the populist nationalist movements that shook up European politics for a decade.

title: House, Mostly Along Party Lines, Censures Gosar for Violent Video
content: The Arizona Republican is the first member of the House to be formally rebuked in more than a decade. He was also removed from two committees.

more_info.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Catie Edmondson

title: Jan. 6 Defendant Known as QAnon Shaman Sentenced to 41 Months
content: Jacob Chansley, who wore a horned helmet and a fur pelt as he stormed onto the Senate floor during the Capitol riot, had earlier pleaded guilty to a single felony count.

title: Catholic Bishops Avoid Confrontation With Biden Over Communion
content: In a vote, they endorsed new guidance on offering holy communion to public figures but did not overtly mention the president or other officials who support abortion rights.

org_facet: United States Conference of Catholic Bishops

title: How Americans’ Appetite for Leather in Luxury SUVs Worsens Amazon Deforestation
content: An examination of Brazil’s immense tannery industry shows how hides from illegally deforested ranches can easily reach the global marketplace. In the United States, much of the demand for Brazilian leather comes from automakers.

more_info.byline: By Manuela Andreoni, Hiroko Tabuchi, Albert Sun and Victor Moriyama

title: Risk for Leader of Belarus: Migrants He Lured May Want to Stay
content: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus, whom the E.U. accuses of engineering a migrant crisis on the border with Poland, could face a serious headache if asylum seekers try to stay in his country.

title: A Green Light at the Window for Migrants
content: An unofficial network of local residents, activists and volunteer medics in Poland has been working to support those who have made it across from Belarus in freezing conditions.

title: How the Belarus Standoff Is Unlike Recent Migrant Crises
content: The images at the Belarus-Poland border look familiar, but this emergency has little in common with previous waves of people from Syria, Myanmar and Afghanistan.

des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

title: What Apple’s New Repair Program Means for You (and Your iPhone)
content: Apple said it would soon provide parts, tools and manuals to those who wanted to fix their own iPhones and Mac computers.

title: The Fight of This Old Boxer’s Life Was With His Own Family
content: Marvin Stein lived an eventful and prosperous life. But a battle among his family over his fortune broke out, and he suddenly found himself powerless to fight for himself.

title: To Honor His Indigenous Ancestors, He Became a Champion
content: Inspired by his great-grandfather’s repeated escapes from an Indigenous boarding school, Ku Stevens, 18, retraced the route. Then he set his sights on winning a Nevada state title.

org_facet: Stewart Indian School Cultural Center and Museum

title: Adele Has a Lot of Big Feelings on ‘30’
content: The British superstar’s first album in six years deals with divorce and moving on, countering misery with virtuosity.

title: One Chaste Marriage, Four Kids, and the Catholic Church
content: A son reflects on his parents’ commitment, endorsed by the Catholic Church, to cohabit chastely like “brother and sister” to avoid mortal sin.

title: The Truth About Kyle Rittenhouse’s Gun
content: Kyle Rittenhouse’s semiautomatic rifle endangered everybody around him —  and himself.

title: The Supply-Chain Crisis Is a Labor Crisis
content: Governments around the world have failed transport workers. But it’s not too late to help them.

title: Democrats Shouldn’t Panic. They Should Go Into Shock.
content: “No administration is going to thrive in that economic environment.”

title: Bosnia Is On the Brink of Breaking Up
content: This is what happened when the West looked away from my country.

title: I’m 87, Triple Vaxxed and Living My Life Again
content: My life expectancy is six more years. Covid-19 can’t prevent me from enjoying the time I have left.

title: Can Covid Winter Be Merry and Bright? We Asked the Experts.
content: Three experts respond to questions from readers about how to navigate another Covid winter.

title: What if Your Kids Never Let You Sleep Again?
content: You can’t control your children’s sleep. And you probably don’t have to.

content: Especially for women of color.

title: When I Unplugged, I Connected With the Truth.
content: I found a great liberation in playing folk music on an acoustic guitar.

content: Workers who retired because of Covid-19 are being enticed to return.

title: ‘Woke’ Went the Way of ‘P.C.’ and ‘Liberal’
content: Progressives can still fall back on “progressive.”

title: The 10 Best Books of 2021: A Virtual Event Announcing Our List
content: On Nov. 30, Times subscribers will be the first to find out what made this year’s 10 Best Books list from editors of The Book Review and a guest, Lena Waithe.

title: Intractable African Crises Flare as Biden’s Top Diplomat Visits Kenya
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken hoped to ease the turmoil engulfing Sudan and Ethiopia in his first trip to sub-Saharan Africa. Both worsened on his first full day.

more_info.byline: By Michael Crowley and Declan Walsh

title: Young Dolph, Promising Memphis Rapper, Shot and Killed at 36
content: Known for collaborating widely and his deadpan bravado, his last solo album, “Rich Slave,” debuted at No. 4 on the Billboard chart last year.

more_info.byline: By Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli

title: Hotter Summer Days Mean More Sierra Nevada Wildfires, Study Finds
content: The research adds to a growing body of work finding that climate change is increasing fire risk in California and elsewhere in the West.

title: N.F.L. Requires Masks and Increases Coronavirus Testing for Thanksgiving
content: After N.F.L. cases more than doubled, the league strengthened its Covid-19 protocols and recommended teams help set up testing for families of players and team staff ahead of the holiday.

title: C.D.C. Investigates Flu Outbreak at University of Michigan
content: There have been 528 cases of the flu on the university’s campus in Ann Arbor, a vast majority in students who have not had flu shots, school officials said.

org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: Supporters Appeal for Clemency for Death Row Inmate in Oklahoma
content: Hundreds of students walked out of schools and activists demonstrated at the State Capitol, urging Gov. Kevin Stitt to commute the sentence of Julius Jones, who is scheduled for execution on Thursday.

title: Script Supervisor Sues Alec Baldwin and Others in ‘Rust’ Shooting
content: A lawsuit filed by the supervisor, Mamie Mitchell, said an injury or death on the set was “a likely result” of the production’s failure to follow safety protocols.

more_info.byline: By Julia Jacobs and Graham Bowley

title: Idaho Lawmaker Is Censured for Doxxing Intern Who Reported Rape
content: Priscilla Giddings, an Idaho state representative, shared a student intern’s personal information after the teenager accused another lawmaker of rape.

title: Second U.S. Case of Monkeypox This Year Is Discovered in Maryland
content: Health officials said there was little risk that the virus, which causes a rare but potentially serious illness, would spread. Both cases this year were identified in travelers who had returned from Nigeria.

title: Pentagon Chief Says More Must Be Done to Prevent Civilian Harm
content: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III gave his first public comments about a U.S. strike in 2019 that killed dozens of women and children in Syria, though he offered few specifics.

more_info.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Dave Philipps

title: Standoff Over Vaccines Between Oklahoma Governor and Pentagon Intensifies
content: The state says its National Guard members do not need to be vaccinated. Pentagon officials say a failure to follow “valid medical readiness requirements” could “jeopardize” the status of troops.

des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

title: Professor Cited as Corruption Expert Is Sentenced for Money Laundering
content: A former University of Miami international studies professor used bank accounts in his name and the name of a company he created to launder about $2.5 million, prosecutors said.

title: Mon Laferte Wants to Give You Goose Bumps
content: The Chilean songwriter released two very different albums in 2021 and is nominated for four Latin Grammy Awards on Thursday night.

title: The ‘Fearless Girl’ Statue Is in Limbo
content: Its permit expires on Nov. 29, but the statue famous for staring down the New York Stock Exchange won’t get a city hearing on a more permanent home until December, at the earliest.

title: The World Cup Loses Its First Star
content: Norway’s failure to qualify for Qatar means Erling Haaland will have to watch from home. Norway has taken it in stride.

title: Maureen Cleave, Pop Journalist and Beatles Confidante, Dies at 87
content: Ms. Cleave’s interview with John Lennon, in which he said the Beatles were “more popular than Jesus,” drew worldwide attention.

title: The Making of Black Ivy Style
content: A new book examines how Black civil rights leaders, jazzmen, artists and writers rewrote the sartorial codes of a largely white elite.

content: The Times wants to hear from you.

title: I Never Expected to Love Full-Time Motherhood
content: A queer woman who once shunned tradition discovers domestic calm in uncertain times.

title: The ‘Sex Talk’ Is Actually a Series of Talks
content: Several psychologists and sexual health experts offer ways to make conversations about sex informative and comfortable for children and parents.

title: All Babies Cry, but How Much Is Too Much?
content: Babies with colic can be incredibly challenging, but thankfully the condition ends on its own.
